data.title: [Request] Fast Scrolling when hotkey pressed (ex: CTRL)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Eclipse has a feature built-in that increases scrolling speed to be one page at a time if ctrl is held, which is very useful for navigating long files.

Intellij has a plugin that supports a similar feature: https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/7573-fast-scrolling

Is it possible to implement something similar for vscode as well? Basically you hold down the control key, and then scroll, and it scrolls much faster than normal.

data.title: VS Code can't find C++ files with a unicode directory name.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10 4.10 Generic Kernel.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a file on a directory with unicode name-more specifically "foreign languages."
2. Try to debug it by setting breakpoints.

This might be the reason for the problem that I have described in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-cpptools/issues/617.

I was able to debug C++ file without any problems when I am debugging a C++ file on a "regular" directory (e.g. /media/username/**DriveName**/username/Documents/Visual Studio 2124/Projects/ProblemName/ProjectName/Bar.cpp).

When the C++ source file is on a directory with any "foreign language" characters, Code says it cannot find the file and shows a strange file location (e.g. /media/username/**354203210 353263274353245250**/username/Documents/Visual Studio 2017/Projects/SolutionName/ProjectName/Foo.cpp).

The issue can be reproduced if you try to debug a C++ file with unicode on a regular folder; the file doesn't have to be on a different drive.

Code can read files with unicode directory name, but Code can't just debug the files since Code couldn't find it.

Other info:
The drive's name (354203210 353263274353245250 in this case) is written in my first language.
The file system of the drive is NTFS.
The C++ files that I had problems with are symbolic links to the C++ files on the NTFS drive.
The drive's name 354203210 353263274353245250 should be "새 볼륨" without quotation marks just in case if you need it.

data.title: [Feature request] Cache files (or something similar)
data.body:
For more info on the problem see #24328 

In summary: can VS Code help us recover files that were permanently deleted by mistake while we were editing them with VS Code?

- A good enough solution would be to add an option to autosave cache files somewhere in %AppData%/Code (assuming Windows environment): i.e. every time we save a file using the editor (or it's saved automatically by the editor), VS Code would also save a copy to the corresponding cache file.
- These cache files could be kept there for a few days (configurable, possibly 1 week after last edit as default).
- (Extra) Add a few commands to CTRL+SHIFT+P to navigate through / search files in that cache.

data.title: No symbols found: scope/navigation UI and gotoSymbol failed on linux
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
## System info
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Linux 4.4.0-72-generic, Ubuntu 16.04.2 LTS
  - this issue have been there at last several system updates. : (

## Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a .cpp file
2. ctrl+shift+o
3. NO symbols found, scope/navigation UI is always in global scope(no matter I'm in global function, member function or class declaration)

## Related settings(I think...maybe)
- "C_Cpp.autocomplete": "Disabled",
- "editor.renderWhitespace": "all",
- "files.encoding": "gbk",
- "[cpp]": {
        "editor.quickSuggestions": true
      },

## Other info
- I have also Windows installed beside Ubuntu(dual boot) and it seems works fine.

data.title: [REQUEST] Open-In-Browser Package for Visual Studio Code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: Windows 10 Build 1607

In Atom, there is a package called "open-in-browsers" that I use extensively. It allows a dev to open their HTML files in the supported browsers(Chrome, Firefox, IE, Opera) with one click. Is there such a package for VSC?

![open-in-broswer](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20476593/24832898/f05876d0-1cba-11e7-86e0-905a76fbf6d9.png)

(Look at the bottom of the editor, do you see the icons? Can that be reproduced for VSC?)
Link to Atom Package -> https://atom.io/packages/open-in-browsers

data.title: Need to zoom only code, not all the interface
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Win 10

When zooming in, all the interface gets bigger. I would expect only the code to be.

It is unecessary to have huge icons, tabs, scrollbars and so on... space for code gets narrow unless you go in zen mode. It kinda beats the purpose in my opinion.

But I can understand for accessibility/usability, it can be good to make the interface bigger. Would that be possible to have another type of zoom only affecting the code?

In general, it's mapped to CTRL+Mousewheel.

Thanks

data.title: Cmd+C (Copy) breaks Undo/Redo history
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1 d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.4 (16E195)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create 10 lines of text.
2. Delete the 5th line.
3. Add 5 more lines to the bottom.
4. Undo back until you see the 5th deleted line.  Copy it (Cmd+C).
5. Attempt Redo and notice the forward history is gone.  You lost the 5 additional lines in Step 3.

This is a pattern I was used to using frequently.  I'll be careful now that I know in vscode it doesn't work the way I'm used to.  But I'll raise it in case others agree its a bug.

data.body:
Fonts in VS Code look blurry and fatter than they should be. This is example with Adobe's font ' Source Code Pro' but the situation doesn't depend on font – simply with some of fonts the blurring is less noticeable. There are 3 examples – with Dreamweaver, with editor Sublime and with VS Code. Dreamweaver's and Sublime's look absolutely identical, VS Code's – blurred and, by the way, wider than two previous. May be the problem is just that VS Code stretches font making it fatter and blurry.

data.title: Very bad design/behavior: vscode closes deleted files auomatically
data.body:
I just lost two days of work (university project) because VS Code automatically closes deleted files! I executed a bad g++ command which removed a .cpp file. If VS Code hadn't closed the file I wouldn't have lost it. I guess that's enough reason to reconsider changing this behavior.

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file in VSCode and start editing it.
2. Remove the file (e.g. CTRL+SHIFT+DEL)
3. VSCode closes the file!

data.title: Support 'code -rw' in running instance and wait until tab gets closed
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
Hello

When opening a file from the command line with `code --wait --reuse-window <file>`, the command waits for the previously opened window to be closed before exiting. It is coherent with the use of `--wait` without `--reuse-window` but it is not very convenient.

One can want to reuse an existing window because it is faster than opening a new window. The small delay before the file has finished opened can be a little annoying when writing a commit message for example (if you don't use git or the upcoming SCM API).

One can also argue that it is easier to only close a tab than close the whole window : <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>w</kbd> instead of  <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>w</kbd>  <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>w</kbd> or  <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>w</kbd> on mac for example

Or maybe there could be a new command-line toggle instead of modifying the behaviour of `--wait`

data.title: virtualenvironment not respected
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.1 (d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39, 2017-04-06T14:00:34.044Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.13|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.0|
|vim|vscodevim|0.6.13|;


---
System:
Mac OS X

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open terminal and activate a new python virtual environment.
2. Open VSCode from the terminal.
3. When you modify a python file you should expect a "pylint not installed" error.
4. Select to install pylint on the error pop-up.

Expected result:
The install operation will be performed in your active virtual environment.

Actual result:
The install operation is performed on the system environment and the pylint error will persist.

data.title: Ubuntu - missing icon when using deb package but not when building from source
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Problem:

The launcher icon on Ubuntu shows a question mark for a prescribed (as prescribed on https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux) install of vscode in an ubuntu:16.04 docker container. Installing instead from source fixes the issue with the question mark icon but there is no clear way to run vscode without having the explorer window open up automatically. It would be nice if setting VSCODE_CWD="" would cause the explorer window not to open up for the source built vscode.

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

Create a docker image of vscode based on the ubuntu:16.04 image using the install instructions from https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux. Add X11 support to the image and run a container for this image. Result is that visual studio code can be made to work properly except that the launcher icon shows a question mark.

On the other hand, if you go the long way and create a docker image that installs vscode from source and build it (for me using node 7.8.0 and electron 1.6.3) the launcher icon shows appropriately through X11. A folder is always opened up using this route though and there wasn't any simple configuration that I could find to override this behavior. The most logical way to me seemed to be setting VSCODE_CWD="" but that didn't work.

data.title: Quick Open shows files that have been deleted
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.12.0-insider (77df7646504961abefe7c735d7a10171abce9d4a, 2017-04-07T06:11:15.956Z)

|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|4.0.5|
|vscode-hexdump|slevesque|1.1.4|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press ctrl+p to show quick open
2. Type something

What happens?
Some files that are inside a directory which has been deleted are listed. Selecting one of these files shows the "error file doesn't exist, do you want to Create a new file":

![vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/24830925/5b2f73c2-1c8f-11e7-8ca1-c32cb27cb89c.png)

Shouldn't "recently opened" only show files that exist?
